description.plain:
Janet Damita Jo Jackson is an iconic R&B/pop artist who has sold over 100 million records worldwide and has amassed a number of awards in her illustrious music career.

Born in Gary, Indiana on May 16, 1966, Janet is the youngest of the Jackson family, who rose to prominence a few years after her birth when they signed with Motown Records. Janet joined the family business when she appeared on The Jacksons variety show in 1976, leading to her role as Penny Gordon in Season 5 of the CBS sitcom Good Times. She released two overlooked albums in the early 1980s—Janet Jackson (1982) and Dream Street (1984)—and continued to act during this time, appearing in Diff'rent Strokes and Fame.

The legend of Janet was created after she connected with the legendary Minneapolis production duo Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis to work on her seminal third album, Control. Control and her following album, 1989’s Rhythm Nation 1814, featured several #1 pop hits and made her a worldwide superstar. The trio would go on work on Janet’s subsequent hit albums, including janet., The Velvet Rope, as well as her 2015 comeback album, Unbreakable.

She has won five Grammy Awards, 11 American Music Awards, and holds nine Guinness World Records, including one for the most expensive video in music history at $7 million for the song “Scream”, the 1995 collaboration with her superstar brother Michael Jackson.

Janet has influenced many pop stars, including Drunk in Love, Lady Gaga, and Rihanna. She was honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 1990, and she was selected for induction into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2019.

songs.full_title: No Sleeep by Janet Jackson (Ft. J. Cole)
songs.title: No Sleeep

description.plain:
“No Sleeep” is the ninth song on Janet Jackson’s eleventh studio album, Unbreakable.

The original solo version was released on June 22, 2015 and was  the first new music from Jackson in five years. A month later she released the album version featuring an additional verse from rapper J. Cole.

“No Sleeep,” a collaboration between Jackson and her longtime producers Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, is a quiet storm ballad about the erotic anticipation of two lovers about to reunite. The atmospheric minimalism of the production can be seen as a continuation of the slow jams found on janet. and The Velvet Rope.

The song was named a Best New Track of 2015 by Pitchfork. It reached #63 on the Billboard Hot 100.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_t0ffY3JvE

songs.full_title: All for You by Janet Jackson
songs.title: All for You

description.plain:
“All For You” was the lead single from the 2001 album All For You by American entertainer Janet Jackson. Written and produced with frequent collaborators Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, “All For You” keeps Janet in the familiar territory of dance music aimed at pop success.

The lyrics are pulled from Jackson’s experience as a newly single woman having recently divorced her second husband Rene Elizondo. In interviews, she admitted to being at dance clubs and desiring attention from men who are largely too intimidated by her status and celebrity to approach her as they might any other woman.

“All For You” made history becoming the first single to be immediately added to every pop, rhythmic, and urban radio format. The song went #1 on the Billboard Pop Charts, Billboard R&B Charts, and Billboard Dance Charts in the US as well as notching top 10 entries in many other countries worldwide.



A cartoonish colorful Dave Meyers-directed music video for the song featured a special breakdown with Janet and her dancers that makes allusion to her own hits “The Pleasure Principle” and “Go Deep” as well as sister Rebbie’s “Centipede” and 1984 fave “Let The Music Play” by Shannon.

The song’s impact eventually won Jackson her 5th Grammy Award, this time for Best Dance Recording.

songs.full_title: If by Janet Jackson
songs.title: If

description.plain:
“If” was the second single released from Janet Jackson’s 1993 album janet. It reached #4 on the Billboard Hot 100.

The song—an amalgam of dance-pop, new jack swing, and industrial—is told from the point of view of a woman having an erotic fantasy about a man she’s watching in a club.

The unapologetically sexual lyrical content and genre-defying sound—not to mention its iconic music video—were further indication that Jackson was fearlessly moving into an edgier chapter of her career.

songs.full_title: Would You Mind by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Would You Mind

description.plain:
“Would You Mind” is an album track from Janet Jackson’s All For You album. Its lyrics were so sexually explicit  (“Kiss you, suck you, taste you, ride you”) that the album was banned by the government of Singapore, as was the previous album The Velvet Rope.

In the US, the album did not contain an explicit lyrics advisory sticker until 3 months after it was released. Record companies avoid stickering albums because retailers like Wal-Mart refuse to stock them. Although, by the time the album was stickered, it had already sold millions of copies.

Unlike most of Janet’s collaborations with Jam & Lewis, production for this track was credited primarily to Dana “Rockwilder” Stinson. Stinson also had a hand in writing and producing “You Ain’t Right,” “Come On Get Up,” “Trust a Try,” and “Feels So Right.”

songs.full_title: Nasty by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Nasty

description.plain:
“Nasty” is the third single released from Control and was created in response to street harassment that she encountered from some “nasty boys”. The song is a funky dance track with some hard-hitting drums and became a signature song for Miss Jackson. The single is certified gold and peaked at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, while topping the R&B/Hip-Hop Singles chart.

The music video was choreographed by Paula Abdul—who also appeared in the video herself—and the song won an American Music Award for Favorite Soul/R&B Single in 1987. The song was included on the Rolling Stone’s list of the 100 Greatest Pop Songs.

In an interview with Rolling Stone in 1993, Janet talked about being harassed by men in the streets of Minneapolis while recording Control:

“The danger hit home when a couple of guys started stalking me on the street. They were emotionally abusive. Sexually threatening. Instead of running to Jimmy or Terry for protection, I took a stand. I backed them down. That’s how songs like ‘Nasty’ and ‘What Have You Done for Me Lately’ were born, out of a sense of self-defense. Control meant not only taking care of myself but living in a much less protected world. And doing that meant growing a tough skin. Getting attitude.”

Producer Jimmy Jam also recounted the song’s inspiration in a 2016 interview with Red Bull Music Academy:

We went to this club one time and there were some guys kind of bothering her. We left her by herself, and we figured she would be OK. We kept an eye on her. She figured it out on her own. She came back over to us and she asked, “Why didn’t you guys help me?” We responded, “Help you out? You’re here. You’re fine. Everything is good.” She said, “Yeah. I guess I am. I’m cool.” We replied, “Yeah. You’re good. You didn’t need us.” And then she said to us, “Those guys were saying nasty things to me. I don’t like nasty boys.” We were like, “OK! So let’s write about it.” This was the spirit of the record.

annotatable.link_title: Nasty by Janet Jackson
annotatable.title: Nasty

body.plain:
“Nasty” is the third single released from Control and was created in response to street harassment that she encountered from some “nasty boys”. The song is a funky dance track with some hard-hitting drums and became a signature song for Miss Jackson. The single is certified gold and peaked at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, while topping the R&B/Hip-Hop Singles chart.

The music video was choreographed by Paula Abdul—who also appeared in the video herself—and the song won an American Music Award for Favorite Soul/R&B Single in 1987. The song was included on the Rolling Stone’s list of the 100 Greatest Pop Songs.

In an interview with Rolling Stone in 1993, Janet talked about being harassed by men in the streets of Minneapolis while recording Control:

“The danger hit home when a couple of guys started stalking me on the street. They were emotionally abusive. Sexually threatening. Instead of running to Jimmy or Terry for protection, I took a stand. I backed them down. That’s how songs like ‘Nasty’ and ‘What Have You Done for Me Lately’ were born, out of a sense of self-defense. Control meant not only taking care of myself but living in a much less protected world. And doing that meant growing a tough skin. Getting attitude.”

Producer Jimmy Jam also recounted the song’s inspiration in a 2016 interview with Red Bull Music Academy:

We went to this club one time and there were some guys kind of bothering her. We left her by herself, and we figured she would be OK. We kept an eye on her. She figured it out on her own. She came back over to us and she asked, “Why didn’t you guys help me?” We responded, “Help you out? You’re here. You’re fine. Everything is good.” She said, “Yeah. I guess I am. I’m cool.” We replied, “Yeah. You’re good. You didn’t need us.” And then she said to us, “Those guys were saying nasty things to me. I don’t like nasty boys.” We were like, “OK! So let’s write about it.” This was the spirit of the record.

songs.full_title: Together Again by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Together Again

description.plain:
Janet Jackson told New Now Next:

[This song was] very personal for me. I lost a lot of friends and people that I worked with to this disease (AIDS). I caught drama for that too: Before I wrote the song, I told some of the people at the label the concept for the song, and they didn’t think it was a good idea—'I don’t think you should do that.‘ I said, 'Why shouldn’t I?’ Because whatever, whatever. I thought, ‘You know, this is really stupid.’ It was in my heart.

Jackson wrote this song with the R&B songwriting/production team Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis and her then-husband Rene Elizondo Jr. Elizondo also directed one of the music videos for the song, which shows Jackson reminiscing in her apartment about a friend she lost.

In Billboard’s Book of Number Ones, Jimmy Jam explained there were two different versions of the intro to this song:

We did one where there was a long intro inspired by Donna Summer’s ‘Last Dance,’ where it started off really slow before kicking into the beat. We thought it was a cool contrast, kicking into the more uptempo, house beat. We always figured radio would play the version that’s immediately fast, but surprisingly enough, a lot of stations played the slow version.

The disco motif was Jackson’s idea. After hearing Nuyorican Soul’s “Runaway,” Jackson was inspired to capture a sound reminiscent of the club scene in New York. She told MTV News:

I listened to that all the time earlier this year—it reminded me of being ten years old in Studio 54 in New York.

The song came together quickly in the studio. Jackson already had the concept, the song title, and the first line “There are times when I look above and beyond.” Jimmy Jam, Terry Lewis and Jackson had a long history of working together (they collaborated on her previous album Rhythm Nation but this song’s process was different from anything they had worked on previously. Usually Jackson will sit with an instrumental for a while and come back with an idea. This song began with Jackson, and was done after a half-hour studio session.

“Together Again” became an international hit, and earned Jackson a Grammy in 1998 (and the rest of the Velvet Rope album earned her another Grammy). This track also helped solidify her reputation as an LGBT ally and a gay icon. Critics speculated about her own sexuality, which she discussed in Ebony in 2001:

I don’t mind people thinking that I’m gay or calling me gay. I love people regardless of sexual preference, regardless of race.

This song brings up ideas of reincarnation. Jackson confirmed in an interview that she doesn’t believe that life definitively ends when someone dies. This is why, despite the song’s elegiac theme, it remains a uplifting, joyous track. She told MTV:

Well I decided that I wanted to do a song about my friends. I wanted to do a song that was uplifting, rejoiceful—that would reflect their personalities. I do believe that it just end here. That they’ve gone into another life. And that I will see them again.

songs.full_title: Got ’Til It’s Gone by Janet Jackson (Ft. Joni Mitchell & Q-Tip)
songs.title: Got ’Til It’s Gone
songs.title_with_featured: Got ’Til It’s Gone (Ft. Joni Mitchell & Q-Tip)

description.plain:
“Got ‘Til It’s Gone” was the lead single from Janet Jackson’s 1997 album The Velvet Rope.

Though Janet’s career-long production team Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis are credited as producers on this #1 song, its bassy neo-soul sound—an entirely different environment for Janet—points to beatsmith J Dilla as the chief architect of its sound. Both Dilla and  Q-Tip were said to be chafed at this slanted producer credit. The duo, collectively known as The Ummah, dealt out their comeuppance by later issuing a remix of the single with the selfsame hallmarks of their original production and titling it “Got ‘Til It’s Gone (Ummah Jay Dee’s Revenge Mix).”

“Got ‘Til It’s Gone” is centered on a sample of Joni Mitchell’s “Big Yellow Taxi” where the folk troubadour sings “Don’t it always seem to go, that you don’t know what you’ve got 'til it’s gone?” Q-Tip echoes back ad-libs throughout the song saying, “Joni Mitchell never lies.”

A Mark Romanek-directed music video for the song won Janet a Grammy Award for Best Music Video – Short Form. Though the themed clip was inspired by a South African magazine called Drum) featured in the video, it was not filmed on location, but in a soundstage in Los Angeles. The video also debuted Janet’s now-iconic four-ponytail hairstyle, also reprised in the music video for the follow-up single “Together Again.”.



Jackson spoke with Jet magazine about the meaning of this song:

“‘Got 'Til It’s Gone’ is about a great lesson learned – appreciate what you have while you have it. In my life, I try to take nothing for granted, even if I don’t always succeed.”

songs.full_title: That's the Way Love Goes by Janet Jackson
songs.title: That’s the Way Love Goes

description.plain:
“That’s The Way Love Goes” was the lead single of Janet Jackson’s fifth album (and first for Virgin Records) entitled janet. The single topped the Billboard Hot 100 chart for 8 weeks, and both the Billboard R&B and Dance charts for 4 weeks each. Boasting platinum sales in the US, it was no surprise when the song won the Grammy for Best R&B Song the following year.

Produced by Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, the song samples a guitar riff from James Brown’s “Papa Don’t Take No Mess” and a drum break from The Honeydrippers' “Impeach The President.”. After being presented the track, Jam says she came up with the lyrics and melody on her own, with the producers contributing the intro line “Like a moth to a flame burned by the fire.”

The music video depicted Janet playing the song for her dancers (who include a then unknown Jennifer Lopez. This new sexy image was only revealed in 1990 during the “Love Will Never Do (Without You)” video shoot. For “That’s The Way Love Goes,” a svelte and fully blossomed Janet donning curly brown hair, a bare midriff, and Native American jewelry.

songs.full_title: I Get Lonely by Janet Jackson
songs.title: I Get Lonely

description.plain:
“I Get Lonely” was the third commercially released single from Janet Jackson’s sixth album The Velvet Rope.

Like many of the other songs on the album, “Lonely” is both unapologetically melancholic and resoundingly melodic. For its radio release, the song was remixed by Teddy Riley and Timbaland featuring Blackstreet, resulting in Jackson’s 18th consecutive top 10 hit.

songs.full_title: Black Cat by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Black Cat

description.plain:
“Black Cat” is the sixth single released from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814, a song written by Janet and co-produced by Jellybean Johnson along with her. The song is a hard rock track among dance tracks and love songs on the album. The song was nominated for a Grammy Award in the Best Female Rock Vocal Performance category, making her the only artist to be nominated in five different genres (R&B, pop, rap, dance, rock). The song reached #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, the third single from the album to achieve that status.

The song finds Janet warning her bad-boy boyfriend that he needs to shift his priorities before he loses both her and his life. Two superstitions/folk tales come into play on the track: cats having nine lives and black cats being a sign of bad luck. Janet sees her man as someone whose lives are quickly running out, and also a negative influence on her.

Producer Jimmy Jam encouraged Janet to tap into her rock side with this song:

One night I told her I wanted her to sound like a Rock and Roll queen on it – she usually uses one of her other voices to sing R&B funk. This, you wanted to be funky, but more rocked out. That was what I was trying to get her to do, and she did it in one or two takes.

Jackson employed a real black leopard during her concerts until some fans became concerned about the cat’s welfare. She announced:

While the illusion with the cat was appreciated by most of the audience, if it caused even a few people to worry about the safety of the cat, it’s not worth keeping it."

Producer Jimmy Jam encouraged Janet to tap into her rock side with this song:

One night I told her I wanted her to sound like a Rock and Roll queen on it – she usually uses one of her other voices to sing R&B funk. This, you wanted to be funky, but more rocked out. That was what I was trying to get her to do, and she did it in one or two takes.

Jackson employed a real black leopard during her concerts until some fans became concerned about the cat’s welfare. She announced:

While the illusion with the cat was appreciated by most of the audience, if it caused even a few people to worry about the safety of the cat, it’s not worth keeping it."

songs.full_title: Dammn Baby by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Dammn Baby

description.plain:
“Dammn Baby” is the third song on Janet Jackson’s eleventh studio album, Unbreakable.

Composed and produced by Jackson with her longtime collaborators Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, the song also features production and writing input from Dem Jointz. Most of the songs on Unbreakable are mid-tempo and feature airy, organic arrangements; “Dammn Baby” is notable for retaining the upbeat, hard-edged sonic density of past Jackson/Jam/Lewis collaborations (but with elements of trap thrown into the mix).

The song’s breakdown includes a sample from Jackson’s 1998 hit “I Get Lonely” from  her acclaimed album The Velvet Rope. The inclusion of the sample can be seen as a victory lap: a nod to the groundbreaking r&b that Jackson, Jam, and Lewis were making seventeen years ago in the midst of their latest boundry-pusher.

songs.full_title: Doesn't Really Matter by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Doesn’t Really Matter

description.plain: “Doesn’t Really Matter” is a single for All For You and the soundtrack Nutty Professor II: The Klumps. The song is about love not being based on your appearance. It reached the top five & ten in other countries and in the US, it peaked at number one on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming her ninth number one there. It’s certified gold by the RIAA and silver by BPI. The music video won “Outstanding Music Video” and “Most Stylish Music Video” at the VH1 Fashion Awards.

songs.full_title: Control by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Control

description.plain:
The title track was released as the fourth single from Control and the album’s opening track as a symbol of Janet Jackson’s independence. The album saw her professionally break away from her father Joe Jackson, who she fired as her manager going into the Control album after her first two albums failed commercially. The superstar production duo Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis were brought in to work with Janet and they helped convey her feelings into the lyrics.

The song peaked at #5 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped both the Dance and R&B charts in 1986. The single was certified Gold by the RIAA. The music video won a Soul Train Music Award for Best R&B/Soul or Rap Music Video in 1988.

songs.full_title: Again by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Again

description.plain:
“Again” is a ballad by Janet Jackson, which appears on her fifth studio album, janet. The song was released as album’s third official single on October 12, 1993.

“Again” became a hit, reaching the #1 spot on the US Billboard Hot 100 for two weeks in 1993. The song was also nominated for a Golden Globe and an Academy Award nominations for Best Original Song, but lost to “Streets of Philadelphia” by Bruce Springsteen.

Lyrically, the song is about reconnecting with a former romantic partner and rekindling a relationship.

songs.full_title: Rhythm Nation by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Rhythm Nation

description.plain:
The title track from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814 was released as the second single and features an industrial dance-pop track mixed with New Jack Swing and a funk guitar sample courtesy of Sly and the Family Stone’s track “Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Again)”. The song has a socially conscious message of being inclusive and “pushing toward a world rid of color-lines”.

The gold single peaked at #2 on the Billboard Hot 100 and reached the top of the Dance Club Songs and Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs charts. The song and its apocalyptic black-and-white military-style music video received a plethora of awards, including a Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video, several Billboard Music Awards, a Soul Train Award for Music Video of the Year, and MTV Video Music Awards for Best Dance Video and Best Choreography in a Video, as well as MTV’s Video Vanguard Award in 1990.

A thoughtful Janet recalled this song 26 years later on “Shoulda Known Better” off her 2015 album, Unbreakable:

I had this great epiphany
And rhythm nation was the dream
I guess next time I’ll know better

Music Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAwaNWGLM0c

songs.full_title: Unbreakable by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Unbreakable

description.plain: “Unbreakable” is the title track of Janet Jackson’s eleventh album. It was released as a promo single on September 3, 2015 in advance of the album’s release three weeks later. The mid-tempo r&b track features Jackson breezily singing about the love and admiration she feels for a romantic partner– which can also be interpreted as a love letter to her fan base. The song was warmly received by critics and fans and was performed as the final number on Jackson’s Unbreakable World Tour in 2015/16.

songs.full_title: No Sleeep (Single Version) by Janet Jackson
songs.title: No Sleeep (Single Version)

description.plain:
Seven years since her last album, Discipline, Janet Jackson returns with her comeback single “No Sleeep” from her long awaited eleventh studio LP, Unbreakable.

The smooth and sexy jam was released digitally on June 23rd, two months before the start of her sold out tour Unbreakable.

songs.title: Funny How Time Flies (When You’re Having Fun)

description.plain: “Funny How Time Flies (When You’re Having Fun)” is the seventh and final single released from Janet Jackson’s breakthrough third album, Control. Although the single didn’t chart as well as the album’s other singles, it still received moderate radio airplay and was sampled multiple times in the following years.

songs.full_title: Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is About You) by Janet Jackson (Ft. Carly Simon)
songs.title: Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is About You)
songs.title_with_featured: Son of a Gun (I Betcha Think This Song Is About You) (Ft. Carly Simon)

description.plain:
“Son of a Gun” was the third single, released on December 11, 2001, from Janet Jackson’s All For You album. In addition to this version, there is also a remix with Missy Elliott.

“Son of a Gun” is plainly directed toward Janet’s ex-husband Rene Elizondo, Jr. with whom she was in the process of divorcing during the recording of the album. The song taunts the former spouse by borrowing the famously cagey lyric “I bet you think this song is about you, don’t you?” from Carly Simon’s “You’re So Vain.”

Simon, happily gave permission for Jam & Lewis to license her song when asked, and is even featured in new “You’re So Vain” vocals for “Son of a Gun.” She also appears reciting a poem called “Clouds” that precedes this song on the All For You album.

description.plain:
“Feedback” is a song by Janet Jackson, released as the lead single from her tenth studio album, Discipline. It fuses electropop and dance, while also incorporating elements of Eurodance and hip hop. It features varied instrumentation, such as guitars, synthesizers and drums.

“Feedback” received acclaim from critics, who praised its sonic innovation and contrast from her prior release, commending Jackson as “back in the form that made her a pop superstar.”

songs.full_title: Miss You Much by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Miss You Much

description.plain:
“Miss You Much” was released as the lead single to Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. The song went on to become Janet’s most successful single, selling over four million copies and topping the Billboard Hot 100 for four weeks, while also reaching #1 on the Dance Club Songs and Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs charts.

Janet received multiple awards for the song, including a Billboard Award for Top Hot 100 Single of the Year, a Soul Train Music Award for Best Female R&B Single, and two American Music Awards for Favorite Soul/R&B Single and Favorite Dance Single. The black-and-white music video was included in the long-form Rhythm Nation 1814 mini-movie and features a choreographed chair routine at the end.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d_E0CRWeIIA

songs.full_title: Velvet Rope by Janet Jackson (Ft. Vanessa-Mae)
songs.title: Velvet Rope

description.plain: The introductory track on the eponymous album, here Janet speaks of her own internal velvet rope (where everyone is allowed to freely be themselves), similar to the velvet rope at a red carpet show. She wishes for everyone to have their wishes inside their respective velvet ropes, while not receiving judgement or hate

songs.full_title: Come Back to Me by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Come Back to Me

description.plain: “Come Back to Me” is the fifth single from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. The R&B ballad tells of a lover wanting their old love back. It reached the top three in both Canada and the US. The music video was uploaded to Youtube on June 16, 2009.

songs.full_title: The Pleasure Principle by Janet Jackson
songs.title: The Pleasure Principle

description.plain:
“The Pleasure Principle” is the sixth single released from Janet Jackson’s Control album. The song was written and produced by Monte Moir, who is a member of the Minneapolis funk group The Time, along with Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis. The music video is considered one of her finest works, as she danced all around an empty loft and performed intricate choreography with a chair, leading her to win an MTV Video Music Award for Best Choreography in 1988.

The single peaked at #14 on the Billboard Hot 100, topped Billboard’s Hot Dance Music/Club Play chart for two weeks in June of 1987, and topped Billboard’s R&B chart for a week in August 1987.

songs.full_title: You by Janet Jackson
songs.title: You

description.plain: This song depicts Janet as fighting an inner battle with a side of herself, one that has created a life that  her “E-C-N-E-I-C-S-N-O-C” is unhappy with.  She notes that she, or “you,” is the only one able to change this life, and the conscience she’s speaking as will never go away.

songs.full_title: Go Deep by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Go Deep

description.plain: “Go Deep” is the fourth single from The Velvet Rope. The funk-inspired R&B song is a party anthem about the healing power of going out with friends and dancing all night. Although the song failed to reach the Billboard Hot 100, it peaked within the top twenty in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. The music video appeared on the DVD edition of 2001’s All for You as well as the video compilation From Janet to Damita Jo: The Videos.

Although the song failed to reach the Billboard Hot 100, it peaked within the top twenty in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. The music video appeared on the DVD edition of 2001’s All for You as well as the video compilation From Janet to Damita Jo: The Videos.

songs.full_title: Escapade by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Escapade

description.plain:
“Escapade” is the third single from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814 and topped the Billboard Hot 100 for three weeks, becoming the second #1 pop single from the album along with the lead single “Miss You Much”. “Escapade” achieved gold status and also topped both the Billboard Dance Club Songs and Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs charts. The upbeat track won a BMI Pop Award as the Most Played Song of 1990.

The song was partially inspired by the 1965 hit “Nowhere To Run” by Martha & the Vandellas, which Janet considered covering for the album, but producer Jimmy Jam recalls how hearing the word “escapade” in a conversation led to the song’s composition:

We usually come up with the music first, then we try to think of a title that fits the way the music sounds. And ‘Escapade’ we thought was a cool word. It is kind of old fashioned — people don’t really say ‘Let’s go on an escapade’ anymore, but it really worked with that track.

Jimmy Jam also described the song’s production and recording process at the Flyte Tyme Studio in Minneapolis:

While she was sitting in one room coming up with the lyrics, I put it on the 24-track. We hooked the drum machine up. On my left hand I played the bass, on the right hand I played the chord. And it was just enough for her to sing to, which we do a lot. Because we like to let her sing to as minimum of a track as we can do, then fill in the track around her so that her part is the main part of the song. With ‘Escapade,’ she sang it and we kept saying we’ll go back and redo the track…we never redid the track. There’s a keyboard bass and another thing, and that was it. All we added were the overdubs, little bells … because we’d gotten so used to the feel of the track, the mistakes and all, we ended up leaving it the way it was.

songs.full_title: Alright by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Alright

description.plain:
“Alright” was the fourth single released from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. Based around a James Brown vocal sample from the Lyn Collins track “Think (About It)”, Janet delivers a funky New Jack Swing dance track about finding love with a true friend. The single peaked at #4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and was her fourth consecutive single to top the Dance Club Songs chart, breaking a record held by Madonna. The song was remixed several times, with one version featuring rapper Heavy D being used in the music video and released as the radio mix. (It’s this version which appears on Janet’s various greatest hits compilations.)

The music video won a Soul Train Music Award for Best R&B/Soul or Rap Music Video. It was created to look like a 1940s musical, with Janet and her friends wearing zoot suits and running into performers from that era, including dancing duo The Nicholas Brothers, actress/dancer Cyd Charisse, and jazz singer/bandleader Cab Calloway.

songs.full_title: What Have You Done for Me Lately by Janet Jackson
songs.title: What Have You Done for Me Lately
songs.title_with_featured: What Have You Done for Me Lately

description.plain:
“What Have You Done For Me Lately”, the lead single from Control, is a general tune about dissatisfaction with one’s partner, but it was written, in part, to convey Jackson’s feelings about the recent annulment of her marriage to singer James DeBarge. The song has been credited as a female empowerment anthem with its message of not settling for less.

The song marked her emergence as an international superstar. The single peaked at number four on the Billboard Hot 100 and was certified gold in the US, while the single also peaked at #1 on the US R&B/Hip-Hop Singles chart and in the Netherlands. The music video was choreographed by Paula Abdul—who also appeared in the video herself—and the video won a Soul Train Music Award for Best R&B/Soul or Rap Music Video in 1987.

songs.full_title: When I Think of You by Janet Jackson
songs.title: When I Think of You

description.plain:
“When I Think of You” is the third single released from Janet Jackson’s third album Control.

On the Billboard Hot 100, the song became the album’s third consecutive top ten hit, as well as Jackson’s first #1 hit in the United States.

The lyrics detail Jackson’s infatuation with her lover, specifically the way he brings her tranquility, and how she never wants to leave him.

songs.full_title: Runaway by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Runaway

description.plain:
“Runaway” is the lead single from Janet Jackson’s first greatest hits collection Design of a Decade 1986/1996. The single showed up just on the heels of “Scream,” her larger-than-life collaboration with brother Michael Jackson in May 1995.

In contrast to that, “Runaway” is a sunshiny, escapist romantic pop song in the vein of “When I Think of You” or “Escapade.” The largely green-screen-shot music video shows Janet in exotic garb with hair in an updo, and a gold chain connecting jewelry in her nose and ear piercings as she dances with her dancers in unusual locales the world-over. The single notched top 10 entries on Billboard’s R&B, Dance, Pop, and Adult Contemporary Charts.

songs.full_title: Let's Wait Awhile by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Let’s Wait Awhile

description.plain:
“Let’s Wait Awhile” is the fifth single from Janet Jackson’s Control album. The song relays a message of abstinence inspired by a conversation the song’s co-writer Melanie Andrews had with her boyfriend during their teenage years. This song’s abstinence message was also promoted as the United States was dealing with the AIDS epidemic around the time this song was created.

“Let’s Wait Awhile” peaked at #2 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped Billboard’s R&B Singles chart for a week in March of 1987.

songs.full_title: Someone to Call My Lover by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Someone to Call My Lover

description.plain:
Released in 2001 as the second single from All for You, “Someone to Call My Lover” became Janet’s 28th and final top ten hit on the Billboard Hot 100, peaking at #3.

The song explores Janet’s desire to find a new lover after her divorce from Rene Elizondo Jr.

The production of “Someone to Call My Lover” is based around a guitar loop sampled from the band America’s song “Ventura Highway”, which Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis brought to Jackson. It also contains a piano loop in the chorus interpolated from Erik Satie’s “Gymnopédie No. 1”, which Jackson remembered from a commercial she saw in her childhood.

songs.full_title: Love Will Never Do (Without You) by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Love Will Never Do (Without You)

description.plain:
Janet Jackson’s “Love Will Never Do (Without You)” was the seventh and final single released from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. In January 1991, it became Janet’s fifth number-one hit on the Billboard Hot 100 and was certified Gold. (It also was the seventh single from the album to reach the US Top 5, making her the first artist to have that many Top 5 hits from one album.)

The upbeat ode to fidelity blended Jackson’s affinity for melodic pop hooks with Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis’s percussive New Jack Swing production. That sonic template and the accompanying video (a sensual black and white video featuring a body-confident Jackson) hinted at the next step in her artistic evolution: 1993’s sex-positive, New Jack pop masterpiece janet..

songs.full_title: Shoulda Known Better by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Shoulda Known Better

description.plain:
“Shoulda Known Better” is the fifth song on Janet Jackson’s eleventh studio album, Unbreakable.

Written and produced by Jackson with her longtime collaborators Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, the song alternates between hushed verses and anthemic EDM-inflected choruses. Lyrically the song could be viewed as a wistful update to/reflection on the “state of society” songs found on Jackson’s 1989 album Rhythm Nation 1814.

Of the song, Jimmy Jam told the BBC:

When you’re young, you feel like: “I can change the world! I’m going to lead the revolution!” And then you look 25 years later and you go: “OK, I should have known better. The same problems still exist but there’s a different way to go about tackling it. It still involves mobilising people, but I can’t do it by myself.”
It’s just a wiser, more mature look at the reality of trying to make a positive change, a social change.

A music video was accompanied and released in 1994. The single/video version featured a guest verse from MC Lyte and light remixing from original producers Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis.

songs.full_title: Every Time by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Every Time

description.plain:
“Every Time” was the sixth and final single from Janet Jackson’s The Velvet Rope album. Lyrically, the ballad is about being cautiously optimistic in romance. The music video has an aquatic theme as a partially nude Janet performs in the nude in a pool while wearing long curly hair and striking icy blue-green contact lenses.

Though it was only released promotionally in the US (notching a modest #125 on the Billboard Pop charts), in the UK it reached #9 on the R&B charts. International releases of the single featured a Jam & Lewis Disco Mix of the ballad that turned it into a uptempo house soundalike of the previous year’s #1 hit “Together Again.”

songs.full_title: Broken Hearts Heal by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Broken Hearts Heal

description.plain:
“Broken Hearts Heal” is the seventh song on Janet Jackson’s eleventh studio album, Unbreakable.

Composed and produced by Jackson with her longtime collaborators Jimmy Jam & Terry Lewis, the song is a reflection on/tribute to her late brother. Like many of the tracks on Unbreakable, “Broken Hearts Heal” begins skeletally: just Jackson’s voice, a keyboard, and kick drum. As the song progresses additional rhythmic elements are added until it reaches the final chorus, where it erupts into an all-out Off the Wall-era disco stomper.

songs.full_title: Where Are You Now? by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Where Are You Now?

description.plain: “Where Are You Now” is a lovelorn midtempo ballad from Janet Jackson’s janet. album. It was intended to be the eighth and final single from the album. It was instead replaced by the Michael & Janet Jackson duet “Scream.” A Nellee Hooper remix of “Where Are You Now” was commissioned for a single release, but eventually included on the janet.remixed compilation.

songs.full_title: Tonight’s the Night by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Tonight’s the Night

description.plain:
Cover of Rod Stewarts “Tonight’s the Night (Gonna Be Alright)” off of his 1976 album A Night on the Town.



The song suggests Jackson losing her virginity to another woman, and also alludes to bisexuality.

Because of the attention received, Stewart announced “that’s an original song by Janet Jackson” when performed in concerts.

In response to the criticism, Jackson said, “I have a lot of gay friends, men and women, and that’s why I did it. I knew people would say I was gay, and I didn’t care.”

songs.full_title: The Knowledge by Janet Jackson
songs.title: The Knowledge

description.plain: “The Knowledge” is one of the social statements on Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. It addresses the importance of education (in different ways) and it goes with the album’s title track, as well as “State of the World” and “Livin' In a World (They Didn’t Make It)” as the “social commentary” part of the record.

songs.full_title: Warmth by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Warmth

description.plain: Keeping true to the sexual nature of Ms. Jackson’s songs on Damita Jo, “Warmth” was a particularly intimate and explicit ballad about performing fellatio on her partner. Along with the female counterpart “Moist” that follows it in sequence on Damita Jo, these two songs dedicated to oral sex attracted a good deal of attention when the album debuted in 2004.

songs.full_title: I Want You by Janet Jackson
songs.title: I Want You

description.plain: “I Want You” is the second single from Damita Jo. The retro-inspired R&B song is about Jackson’s passion for her lover. Just like “Just a Little While”, the single failed in the US due to the Super Bowl Halftime performance that led to her being blacklisted. It only peaked at number fifty-seven on the US Billboard Hot 100. The single is certified platinum by the RIAA and received a Grammy nomination for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance. A music video was released for the single.

songs.full_title: State of the World by Janet Jackson
songs.title: State of the World

description.plain: “State of the World” is a song inspired by news stories regarding social issues such as homelessness. The song was released as the eighth and final single from Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814, but the single was only released to radio and not commercially, making it ineligible for inclusion on the Billboard sales charts; however, it peaked at #5 on Billboard’s Hot 100 Airplay chart.

songs.full_title: Moist by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Moist

description.plain: Like the song before it on Damita Jo, “Moist” is a sensual, uptempo ode to oral sex. However, rather than fellatio, this time Janet focuses her attention on cunnilingus. Together, these two songs on Damita Jo became lightning rods for attention due to their overt sexuality, just as “Would You Mind” did on All For You due to its explicit sexual content.

songs.full_title: So Excited by Janet Jackson (Ft. Khia)
songs.title: So Excited

description.plain: “So Excited” is the second single from 20 Y.O.. The single is a mixture of R&B, hip hop, and dance. The song wasn’t successful on the Billboard Hot 100 (peaking at number ninety), however, but it become Jackson’s seventeenth number-one dance hit on the US Billboard Hot Dance Club Play in the country. A music video for the song was released, directed by Joseph Kahn.

songs.full_title: Whoops Now by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Whoops Now

description.plain: “Whoops Now” is the seventh single from janet.. The song was successful oversees; it reached the top-ten in Austria, France, and the United Kingdom. It was a number-one single in New Zealand for one week. The music video appeared on the video compilation Design of a Decade 1986/1996.

songs.full_title: Rock With U by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Rock With U

description.plain:
“Rock with U” was the second commercially released single from Janet Jackson’s tenth album, Discipline.

The disco-pop track is, on the surface, about falling in love/lust on the dance floor, but is also a sexy-sad love letter to dance music broadly and an homage to her brother’s disco classic of the same name specifically.

songs.full_title: The Skin Game by Janet Jackson
songs.title: The Skin Game

description.plain:
“The Skin Game” is a b-side from Janet Jackson’s single “Come Back to Me”, released as the fifth single from the album Rhythm Nation 1814 in 1990.

The song’s lyrics deal with the racial climate in the United States at the time of its release. They metaphorically refer to the difficulties experienced by minorities trying to get ahead as the “skin game”, implying that one is forced into playing along with it in order to succeed, however they must first figure out how it is played.

songs.full_title: Gon' B Alright by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Gon’ B Alright

description.plain:
Unbreakable finishes with an uplifting classic old school type jam, a resolution similar to ending janet, with the Motown stomper “Whoops Now.”

Janet again acknowledges the daily importance of love in everything people do, and in the fight against low mood and cynicism.

The musical style–with its funky backing and the trade-off between the female and male vocals–is reminiscent of Sly and the Family Stone.

According to Janet’s chief collaborator Jimmy Jam (interviewed by the BBC), the ‘male’ and ‘female’ voices are all done by Janet singing in different “characters”, and in one case (the deepest one) with the help of technology.

songs.full_title: Racism by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Racism

description.plain: After the heavy focus on social issues with the Rhythm Nation 1814 album, Janet took a sharp departure to explore love and sex on janet. However, with this interlude, and its follow-up song “New Agenda,” she acknowledges that the issues she attacked on Rhythm Nation are still in her peripheral vision.

songs.full_title: Because of Love by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Because of Love

description.plain:
“Because of Love” was the fourth single released from Janet Jackson’s 1993 album janet.

The song — an ebullient ode to fidelity — reached the Billboard Top 10 in March of 1994. It’s considered one of the final hits of the new jack swing era.

songs.full_title: China Love by Janet Jackson
songs.title: China Love

description.plain:
In China Love, Janet uses traditional Oriental textures such as chimes and tablas, as Jackson rhapsodizes about past-life romance and new age ambiguities.



Janet had written the song about her own prior identity in another time, in which she was told to be the daughter of an emperor in love with a warrior, unable to sustain relations when forced to marry into royalty.

songs.full_title: Twenty Foreplay by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Twenty Foreplay

description.plain:
“Twenty Foreplay,” titled after a combination of “foreplay” and “24 hours a day,” was the second of two new songs released as singles from Janet Jackson’s first greatest hits collection Design of a Decade 1986/1996. The wistful song about the joys of sexual foreplay got a glitzy makeover for its single remixes by Jorge “G-Man” Corante.



And the remixes weren’t the only notable upgrade. For the black-and-white music video, Janet got an old Hollywood makeover, sporting the glamorous style of singer/actress Dorothy Dandridge. The video was part of a soft campaign to play the actress in a biopic about her life. Though she and fellow superstar Whitney Houston were both vying for the role, the role ultimately went to Halle Berry in Introducing Dorothy Dandridge.

Ultimately, the single (which was only commercially released in the UK) would become a Top 5 R&B hit there, and notching a respectable #32 on the R&B/Hip-Hop airplay charts in America.

songs.full_title: Love U 4 Life by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Love U 4 Life

description.plain:
“Love U 4 Life” is a bonus track that only appears on certain editions of Janet Jackson’s Unbreakable album (Japanese import, Target exclusive, etc).

Since marrying Wissam Al Mana and converting to Islam, Janet’s hallmark hypersexual content has been dramatically tamed. While the sound of “Love U 4 Life” is vaguely reminiscent of The Jacksons' “This Place Hotel” or Michael Jackson’s “I Can’t Help It,” the lyrics are only slightly sensual by comparison to the fully-PG fare of Unbreakable overall.

description.plain: Sounding almost like a holdover from the 1940s vibes of “Rhythm Nation”’s “Alright,” “Funky Big Band” shifts the settings from Minneapolis to Harlem on this tribute to famed jazz club Lennox Lounge. “Got to be real,” Janet advises. “He who knows it feels it. Janet’s vocals along with the jazz/funk type sound is amazing.

songs.full_title: Luv by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Luv

description.plain:
This was written and produced by Rodney Jerkins. Jackson raved to MTV News about working with Jerkins: “It was great working with Rodney. There’s a connection there between the two of us, for sure. He feels it; he’s mentioned it to me. I felt it, but I wasn’t gonna say anything to him about it. [She laughs.] There’s a connection with everyone I work with, but definitely a much stronger connection between [me and] Rodney and Jermaine (Jermaine Dupri Jackson’s boyfriend and head of urban music at Island). He just got me. Either someone is gonna get you or they’re not. They all did, all the producers that I worked with on this project. But Rodney really got me, he understood me. It’s like having a lost brother or cousin; he really understands me. There’s a very good chemistry.”
Jerkins also gushed to MTV about Jackson: “We definitely have this incredible chemistry, this bond – I think we musically connect, crazily. I knew it – it’s funny ‘cause I predicted this. Five years ago, people used to ask me who I wanted to work with, and I was like, 'Janet Jackson.’ And I was so passionate about that because I’ve always been a fan of her music and what her and Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis have done in the past. And I felt like, knowing she wants to try new things, that I feel I can get it and I can deliver it for her.”

songs.lyrics:
I close my eyes and fantasize
And I just imagine a tropical island
We're all alone, our pagers and cell phones cut off
Hot sunny heat, cool ocean breeze

songs.full_title: One More Chance by Janet Jackson
songs.title: One More Chance

description.plain: “One More Chance” is a cover of a song by The Jacksons' from their 1984 album Victory, written by Janet’s brother Randy. The considerably smoothed-out ballad benefits from Jam & Lewis' deft R&B production. The song first debuted as a B-side to Janet’s hit single “If” and makes appearances on special editions of the janet. album as well as the proper janet.remixed album.

songs.full_title: Just a Little While by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Just a Little While

description.plain: “Just a Little While” is the lead single from Damita Jo. The song leaked ahead of its scheduled release, which caused the single and its promotions to be rushed. The single wasn’t as successful as people thought it would be (peaked at number forty-five on the Billboard Hot 100) due to the controversial Super Bowl Halftime Show performance incident, and Jackson was blacklisted on many music radios. It was a success outside the US, reaching the top ten in Belgium, Canada, and Spain and the top twenty in Australia and The United Kingdom. The music video was released exclusively in international territories as Janet at the time was “controversial”.

description.plain: “Can’t B Good” is an R&B ballad released as the fourth and final single from Discipline. The song was written and produced by Ne-Yo. He is probably best known for his transatlantic chart-topper “So Sick.” Ne-Yo also contributed to several other songs from the album including the second single “Rock With U.”

songs.full_title: And On and On by Janet Jackson
songs.title: And On and On

description.plain:
“And On And On” is a non-album track by Janet Jackson. The song first debuted as a B-side to the single “Any Time, Any Place.” The song was later included on the compilation album janet.remixed album with other B-sides like “One More Chance” and “70’s Love Groove” from that era.

Sonically, it rests heavily on a sampled section of Sly & The Family Stone’s “Family Affair,” with little other rhythmic elements masking the sample, which is a first. Before 1992, this was virtually unheard of in Jam & Lewis’s music production.

As a cult favorite among fans, “And On And On” has never been performed live except for on a select few dates of the Janet. World Tour. It did however turn up recently in a DJ set list of deep cuts prepared to warm-up the crowd before Janet’s Unbreakable World Tour.

body.plain:
“And On And On” is a non-album track by Janet Jackson. The song first debuted as a B-side to the single “Any Time, Any Place.” The song was later included on the compilation album janet.remixed album with other B-sides like “One More Chance” and “70’s Love Groove” from that era.

Sonically, it rests heavily on a sampled section of Sly & The Family Stone’s “Family Affair,” with little other rhythmic elements masking the sample, which is a first. Before 1992, this was virtually unheard of in Jam & Lewis’s music production.

As a cult favorite among fans, “And On And On” has never been performed live except for on a select few dates of the Janet. World Tour. It did however turn up recently in a DJ set list of deep cuts prepared to warm-up the crowd before Janet’s Unbreakable World Tour.

songs.full_title: 70's Love Groove by Janet Jackson
songs.title: 70's Love Groove

description.plain: “‘70s Love Groove” is an R&B ballad–one of the slow jams that Janet commonly refers to as a “baby-making song”–recorded during the janet. sessions. Originally released as the b-side to “You Want This”, it gained more attention when it was included on the soundtrack to the 1994 fashion farce Ready to Wear.

description.plain:
This is a track that was recorded for the scheduled Scandal album, which was later changed to 1989’s Janet Jackson’s Rhythm Nation 1814. It was released as the B-side to the album’s lead single “Miss You Much.”

The song is about Janet’s father, Joe Jackson.

songs.full_title: Make Me by Janet Jackson
songs.title: Make Me

description.plain:
Written and recorded for inclusion on Janet Jackson’s second greatest hits compilation, Number Ones (2009), “Make Me” is an upbeat dance track which combines two of Jackson’s greatest strengths: creating infectious songs for the club and making risqué double entendres sound breezy.

As befitting the album from which it originated, “Make Me” was Jackson’s nineteenth #1 single on the Billboard Hot Dance Club Songs chart.
